findings.title: Re-entrancy in SwoopsMint Leads To Maximum Total Supply Violation
findings.description: A reentrancy exploit can occur when external contract calls are made in `mint` and `whitelistedMint` functions via `safeMint`'s `onERC721Received` check, which passes transaction execution to the address of the NFT minter.

findings.title: Missing Input Validation
findings.description: Input validation for protocol configuration and administration is critical as the misseting of any parameters can cause the protocol not to behave as expected.

findings.title: Unrestricted Mint for Owners
findings.description: The owner can mint an arbitrary number of tokens for themselves directly without going through the minting contract, bypassing the maxTokenSupply check.

findings.title: Unlocked Pragma
findings.description: Every Solidity file specifies in the header a version number of the format `pragma solidity (^)0.8.*` . The caret ( `^` ) before the version number implies an unlocked pragma, meaning that the compiler will use the specified version _and above_ , hence the term "unlocked".

findings.title: Surplus ETH Not Refunded
findings.description: As constructed, users may (accidentally) send extra ETH to mint functions. The contract does not return the surplus ETH to the caller.

findings.title: Missing Rescue Tokens
findings.description: It is possible that some tokens accidentally get sent to contracts.

findings.title: High Royalty Fees Can be Imposed Without Users’ Consent
findings.description: The owner can decide to impose high royalty fees at any time to all tokens in circulation.

findings.title: renounceOwnership Can Lead to DoS
findings.description: The inherited Ownable contract comes with a `renounceOwnership` that sets address 0 as the owner, which may have catastrophic consequences on the project including funds being locked in the contract.

findings.title: Incompatible With Proxies
findings.description: Constructors in Solidity can only be executed on contract deployment, therefore they are incompatible with proxies which can only run already deployed code.

findings.title: Vague Superuser Permissions
findings.description: The `owner` role lacks separation of responsibility, creating a single point of failure, with no documentation on safety controls.
